docs.lead_paragraph: Here's a blast from the past. While everyone is talking about Medicare, Lynda Bird Johnson Robb is stepping up to remind everyone that it was her father, former President Lyndon B. Johnson, who signed Medicare into law in the first place.

headline.main: L.B.J.'s Daughter Defends Medicare, Her Father's Legacy

docs.abstract: In a short video, Lynda Bird Johnson Robb urges universal coverage and defends her father's legacy.
docs.snippet: In a short video, Lynda Bird Johnson Robb urges universal coverage and defends her father's legacy.

docs.lead_paragraph: At the core of the proposal to revamp the nation's health care system is the creation of a government-regulated marketplace. On such an exchange, consumers would be able to shop for insurance, compare benefits and prices, and choose a plan that best suits their needs.
docs.abstract: A quick guide to understanding the principle, and the politics, of the "insurance exchange."
docs.snippet: A quick guide to understanding the principle, and the politics, of the "insurance exchange."

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama may not have much trouble persuading the nearly 160 million people who have health insurance through their employers that the system needs to be fixed, if a new survey of employer health benefits is any indication.

headline.main: Insurance Premiums Still Rising Faster Than Inflation and Wages

docs.abstract: The average cost of a family health insurance policy now exceeds $13,000 a year, having doubled over the last decade, according a new survey by the Kaiser Family Foundation.
docs.snippet: The average cost of a family health insurance policy now exceeds $13,000 a year, having doubled over the last decade, according a new survey by the Kaiser Family Foundation.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama winds his way through union territory and back on Tuesday, meeting with workers at a General Motors plant in Ohio and speaking to the A.F.L.-C.I.O. national convention in Pittsburgh.

headline.main: The Early Word: Labor and Health Focus

docs.abstract: While the president tends to union groups, health care continues to dominate legislative moves on the Hill.
docs.snippet: While the president tends to union groups, health care continues to dominate legislative moves on the Hill.

docs.lead_paragraph: T.R. Reid was a bureau chief in Tokyo and London for The Washington Post. His new book, "The Healing of America: A Global Quest for Better, Cheaper, and Fairer Health Care," is a systematic study of the health systems in seven countries that was inspired in part by his family's experiences living overseas and receiving health care abroad. Mr. Reid also produced a 2008 documentary on the same topic for PBS called "Sick Around the World." He spoke with blog contributor Anne Underwood.

headline.main: Health Care Abroad: Questions for T.R. Reid

docs.abstract: Author T.R. Reid examined health care systems in seven developed countries. His verdict: the United States can do better.
docs.snippet: Author T.R. Reid examined health care systems in seven developed countries. His verdict: the United States can do better.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama on Monday sternly admonished the financial industry and lawmakers to accept his proposals to reshape financial regulation to protect the nation from a repeat of the excesses that drove Lehman Brothers into bankruptcy and wreaked havoc on the global economy last year, Stephen Labaton and Jeff Zeleny write in The New York Times.

headline.main: For Obama, Chance to Reform the Street Is Fading

docs.abstract: President Obama sternly admonished the financial industry and lawmakers to accept his proposals to reshape financial regulation. But with the markets slowly healing, Mr. Obama's plan to revamp financial rules faces a diminishing political imperative.
docs.snippet: President Obama sternly admonished the financial industry and lawmakers to accept his proposals to reshape financial regulation. But with the markets slowly healing, Mr. Obama's plan to revamp financial rules faces a diminishing political imperative.

docs.lead_paragraph: Two Republican senators have requested numerous major changes in a Finance Committee proposal on health care, reducing the chances that they will support the measure.

headline.main: New Objections to Baucus Health Care Proposal
headline.print_headline: New Objections to Baucus Health Care Proposal

docs.snippet: Two Republican senators have requested numerous major changes in a Finance Committee proposal on health care, reducing the chances that they will support the measure.

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

docs.lead_paragraph: Lehman Brothers’ bankruptcy meant a former employee lost the severance package and benefits she was promised.

headline.main: Last Days of Lehman: Robbed by the Bank
headline.print_headline: Last Days of Lehman: Robbed By the Bank

docs.lead_paragraph: Devices like iPhones and netbook PCs that can help the speech-impaired are not covered by Medicare or insurers.
docs.snippet: Devices like iPhones and netbook PCs that can help the speech-impaired are not covered by Medicare or insurers.

docs.lead_paragraph: An author’s trip around the world with a sore shoulder teaches a lot about the health care system in the United States.

headline.main: One Injury, 10 Countries: A Journey in Health Care
headline.print_headline: One Injury, 10 Countries: A Journey in Health Care
